author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Need Some Coastal Escape? Got Gold Rush Fever? Explore These State Parks.
description: These five parks represent only a small fraction of California’s extensive park system, but they offer lots of summertime adventure.
content: Kids are out of school, the weather is balmy in much of the state and the days are long — it’s time for summer travel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aruna D'Souza
title: Where’s the Controversy in ‘Philip Guston Now’?
description: The show makes its final U.S. stop at the National Gallery without feared protests. But some caricatures in the artist’s “Poor Richard” series need better explanation.
content: When “Philip Guston Now” opened at the National Gallery of Art in Washington this spring, I could practically hear the collective sigh of relief on my Instagram feed. In 2020, shortly after the murder of George Floyd in Minneapolis and the nationwide protests that followed, the four museums organizing a retrospective of his work announced a four-year delay of the exhibition, citing the need to make sure they were contextualizing Guston’s paintings — which include a series of cartoonish images of Klansmen as bumbling Keystone Kops — with proper sensitivity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: University Departures Put Student Journalists in Spotlight
description: The president of Stanford and the head football coach at Northwestern left their positions after being scrutinized in campus newspapers.
content: Two prominent departures at top universities this month have a common link: inquisitive student journalists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise
title: Microsoft and Activision Delay Deal to Settle British Regulatory Issues
description: The extension is most likely a signal that the companies believe they will eventually receive needed approvals.
content: Microsoft and Activision Blizzard said on Wednesday that they were delaying a $69 billion merger as the two companies scrambled to get final approval from British antitrust regulators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jake Nevins
title: ‘Break Point’ Is the Best Way to See the Full Psychodrama of Tennis
description: The Netflix docuseries gets the highs and lows of the pro circuit right.
content: In the sixth episode of the Netflix docuseries “Break Point,” Ajla Tomljanovic, a journeywoman tennis player who has spent much of the last decade in the Top 100 of the world rankings, is shown splayed across an exercise mat in a drab training room after reaching the 2022 Wimbledon quarterfinals. Her father, Ratko, stretches out her hamstrings. She receives a congratulatory phone call from her sister and another from her idol-turned-mentor, the 18-time major champion Chris Evert, before Ratko announces that it’s time for the dreaded ice bath. “By the way,” Tomljanovic says at one point, “do we have a room?” Shortly after his daughter sealed her spot in the final eight of the world’s pre-eminent tennis tournament, Ratko was seen on booking.com, extending their stay in London.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Actors’ Strike Won’t Halt 39 Independent Projects, Union Says
description: SAG-AFTRA confirmed the productions had no ties to the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers, which represents big studios. More exemptions could follow.
content: The Hollywood actors’ union said Tuesday that it had exempted 39 independent film and TV projects from its strike, including two movies from A24, the secretive New York company that has become a force at the Academy Awards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang and David McCabe
title: Biden Administration Unveils Tougher Guidelines on Mergers
description: The proposed road map for regulatory reviews, last updated in 2020, includes a focus on tech platforms for the first time.
content: The Biden administration’s top antitrust officials unveiled tougher guidelines against tech mergers on Wednesday, signaling their deepening scrutiny of the industry despite recent court losses in their attempts to block tech deal-making.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: Is It Ever Morally Acceptable to Visit a Confederate Historical Site?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on tourism at Beauvoir, the former home of Jefferson Davis.
content: I recently moved back home to Biloxi, Miss., and I’m wondering about visiting the lavish grounds of Beauvoir, the historical site and home of Jefferson Davis, the president of the Confederate States of America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder and Jin Yu Young
title: Jiyai Shin Won a British Open at Royal Liverpool. She’s Got Some Advice.
description: Shin, who won by nine strokes in 2012, walks The Times through five holes that will test the men at the 151st Open.
content: It is easy to forget, given just how thoroughly Jiyai Shin romped to victory at the 2012 Women’s British Open, that she did not lead from start to finish. But her triumph at Royal Liverpool, the English club often known simply as Hoylake, nevertheless stands as one of the most commanding performances in the tournament’s history.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Popcast (Deluxe): Fans Misbehaving at Concerts, and Pinkydoll’s NPC TikTok
description: Plus: Music from Troye Sivan and Militarie Gun (as performed by Post Malone).
content: This week’s episode of Popcast (Deluxe), the weekly culture roundup show on YouTube hosted by Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, includes segments on:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Vance
title: Our Favorite Workouts So Far This Year
description: Halfway through 2023, find the exercise that will help you finish the year strong — no matter your fitness level.
content: It’s mid-July, which means that summer, as well as 2023, is about halfway over. Now is a good time to get outside and get active, whether running, biking or just splashing in the water with friends and family. It’s also a great time to build good exercise habits that can carry you through the rest of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Dermot Doran, Priest Who Rallied Aid for Biafran Airlift, Dies at 88
description: In 1968, Father Doran, who had been in Nigeria as an educator, became the linchpin of one of the largest civilian humanitarian efforts in history.
content: The cargo plane flew in low over southeastern Nigeria, its lights out, its radio off, its pilot navigating by the glow of refinery flares along the coast. The runway, somewhere below, was dark. The pilot dropped his wheels and nosed the plane downward, seemingly into the void.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan O'Callaghan
title: A Cow, a Camel and a Finch Exploded in Space. What Is Going On?
description: Astronomers have yet to determine the cause of luminous fast blue optical transients, and the latest they have detected is raising even more questions.
content: What do a cow, a koala, a camel, a Tasmanian devil and now a finch all have in common?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Why Odesa Is So Important to Ukraine in the War With Russia
description: Russia’s withdrawal from a U.N.-backed grain deal and its attacks on Odesa have brought the Black Sea port city’s importance back into focus.
content: The last two nights have brought some of the most furious Russian aerial assaults on Odesa, the southern Ukrainian port city, of the nearly 17-month-long war. The city on the Black Sea has long been Ukraine’s link to the global economy and home to its busiest ports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: At BroadwayCon, Diversity in Theater Takes Center Stage
description: The eighth annual fan event will host a variety of discussions about how to diversify stages, songs and scripts. Here are six to look out for.
content: It’s the most musical time of the year, the weekend when thousands of fans from around the world descend on Midtown Manhattan for costume contests, Playbill swaps and theater idol meet-and-greets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: I.R.S. Whistle-Blowers Allege Political Bias in Hunter Biden Investigation
description: Two veteran investigators spent several hours detailing to a House committee the ways in which they believed President Biden’s son received preferential treatment.
content: Two veteran I.R.S. investigators leveled harsh criticism on Wednesday against the Justice Department over its handling of the tax case against Hunter Biden, accusing the agency of shielding him from felony charges because of politics and preferential treatment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor and Johnny Diaz
title: Floods Sweep Southwestern Kentucky
description: Graves County, on the border with Tennessee, received more than 11 inches of rain, leading to “flooding like many have never seen,” the authorities said.
content: Strong thunderstorms and heavy rain caused significant flooding in southwestern Kentucky on Wednesday, breaking one daily rainfall record and prompting the authorities to scramble to rescue residents from rising waters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia O'Malley
title: Starving Orcas and the Fate of Alaska’s Disappearing King Salmon
description: With the fish numbers at historic lows, scientists, chefs and others are asking whether we should be eating them anymore, and what it means for the future of all wild salmon.
content: In the waters of Puget Sound outside Seattle, 73 beloved and endangered orcas, known as the Southern Residents, are on the hunt, clicking. Using sound like a searchlight, they patrol the chilly depths. When they locate a target, they dive, sinking sharp white teeth into their preferred food, the fatty coral-colored flesh of king salmon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Rosen
title: Quadruplets With Schizophrenia? Researchers Were Confounded.
description: “Girls and Their Monsters,” by Audrey Clare Farley, recounts the tragic story of the Genain sisters, seeing the subjects at the crossroads of psychiatric and societal forces.
content: Sixty years ago, a psychologist at the National Institute of Mental Health named David Rosenthal published a famous but now largely forgotten study of four sisters with schizophrenia, quadruplets born to Carl and Sadie Morlok in 1930. The Morlok quadruplets — renamed Genain in the scientific literature — had grown up in the same house, and come from the same fertilized egg, but did not appear to have the same version of the disease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Facing a Future of Drought, Spain Turns to Medieval Solutions and ‘Ancient Wisdom’
description: Acequias, a network of water channels created by the Moors over 1,000 years ago, are being excavated and brought back to life to adapt to the crises of climate change.
content: High in Spain’s southern mountains, 40 or so people armed with pitchforks and spades cleared stones and piles of grass from an earthwork channel built centuries ago and still keeping the slopes green.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Newly Published, From a Bayou Thriller to Drugs in America
description: A selection of recently published books.
content: DOWN WITH THE POOR!, by Shumona Sinha. Translated by Teresa Lavender Fagan. (Deep Vellum, paperback, $16.95.) After a Bengali interpreter who works with asylum seekers in Paris is charged with assaulting a refugee, her resulting self-examination lays bare the callousness of France’s asylum system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: China Rebuffed U.S. Calls for Tougher Climate Action
description: Also, Stanford’s president will resign. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
content: President Biden’s climate envoy, John Kerry, traveled to Beijing this week in hopes of persuading officials there to start reducing China’s carbon emissions on a faster timeline. After all, China is responsible for nearly a third of global emissions, and scientists say that its decisions — along with those of the U.S. — will be vital in the fight to stave off the most catastrophic impacts of climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: The Curse Stalking Women’s Soccer
description: The World Cup is missing some of the sport’s biggest stars because of a knee injury epidemic. No one can say for sure why it’s happening, or how to fix it.
content: The third time around, Megan Rapinoe’s reaction to a potentially career-ending knee injury went no further than an eye roll. She had torn her anterior cruciate ligament. She could reel off the recovery schedule from the top of her head. She could see, crystal clear, the next nine to 12 months spooling out in front of her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: One Economist Is Challenging How We Think Money Works
description: It’s “a surprisingly slippery concept,” he says.
content: What’s the difference between $100 in cash and $100 in a checking account? Nothing — and everything. The two are the same in the sense that they’re equally spendable and freely convertible from one form to the other. But the paper bill in your hand is an obligation of the federal government, while the electronic entry is an I.O.U. from your bank. Their interchangeability at a rate of one to one is not a fact of nature but a social construct. So, not the same.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Ben Casselman
title: The Pandemic’s Labor Market Myths
description: Amid the pandemic, people thought the labor market had permanently changed in important ways. It was a bad bet.
content: Remember the “she-cession”? What about the early-retirement wave, or America’s army of quiet quitters?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Copeland
title: Steep Profit Fall at Goldman Sachs Highlights Wall St. Giant’s Woes
description: The investment bank reported a profit half as large as its rival Morgan Stanley, to say nothing of larger lenders.
content: Goldman Sachs on Wednesday reported quarterly profit that fell short of even dampened expectations, another reminder of the troubles facing one of Wall Street’s premier names.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Can I Watch ‘Barbenheimer’ Despite the Hollywood Strikes?
description: People sympathetic with the strikers may be concerned, but the actors’ and writers’ unions say it’s OK to go to the movies and use streaming services.
content: A clip from the sitcom “The Nanny” has been making the rounds on social media. It shows Fran Fine — played by Fran Drescher, the current Screen Actors Guild president — telling her boss one of her mother’s three cardinal rules: “Never, ever, ever cross a picket line.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Kiehart
title: It’s an Honor to Wear This Jersey. It’s Also Kind of a Pain.
description: The yellow jersey worn by the Tour de France race leader can sometimes be an uncomfortable fit.
content: Jonas Vingegaard had been wearing the famed yellow jersey bestowed upon the leader of the Tour de France for almost a week when the question came.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jori Finkel
title: Watching for the Bus Stop Gallery
description: Felipe Baeza’s “Unruly Forms” are coming to bus shelters in the U.S. and Mexico. Merging painting and printmaking, his images explore the displacement of migrants and antiquities.
content: The artist Felipe Baeza knows something about waiting for the bus. Growing up in Chicago in the 1990s, he rode the city bus on his own starting around age nine. Going to college at Cooper Union in New York to study art, he took the bus or subway from his home in Spanish Harlem to get to class. This year, living in Los Angeles for a period without a car, he’d take a bus — or two or three — to get across town, though he sometimes gave up after an absurdly long wait and called an Uber.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko, Erin Nolan and Ellen Yan
title: For Families of Other Gilgo Beach Victims, an Agonizing Wait Goes On
description: Authorities continue to investigate whether 8 other corpses found along miles of sand are linked to Rex Heuermann, who they say is a serial killer.
content: Jasmine Robinson sat in a Suffolk County courthouse Friday, listening intently as prosecutors explained how they had tracked a man they suspected of killing and burying at least three women on Long Island’s South Shore. She heard how they had used DNA painstakingly harvested from his pizza crusts, triangulated his mobile phone signals and spent hours on old-school, shoe-leather stakeouts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Jason Aldean Video for ‘Try That in a Small Town’ Pulled Amid Backlash
description: The country singer, who released the song in May, said the tune is an ode to the “feeling of a community” he had growing up. Critics say it is offensive.
content: Country Music Television has pulled a music video for the song “Try That in a Small Town,” by the country music superstar Jason Aldean, which was filmed at the site of a lynching, amid accusations that its lyrics and message are offensive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh
title: Trump Promotes ‘Sound of Freedom,’ a Conservative Hit About Child Predators
description: Hosting a screening at his private club, the former president is the most prominent Republican to embrace a film lauded by both mainstream conservatives and far-right QAnon believers.
content: Senator Tim Scott of South Carolina called it an “amazing, gut-wrenching, emotional movie.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Buckley
title: Want to Help Feathered Friends Beat the Heat? Get a Birdbath.
description: A well-placed, properly maintained birdbath can be a vital resource for birds and other wildlife, and needn’t attract mosquitoes
content: Record temperatures, drought, smoky air and loss of habitat make it increasingly difficult for feathered and other winged creatures in urban and suburban areas to find the water they need.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Martin, Julia Botero, Christina Djossa, Hans Buetow, Jen Poyant, Sara Sarasohn, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Rowan Niemisto
title: My Invisible Husband
description: David Khalaf’s family hid his husband Constantino from his 96-year-old grandmother for years.
content: The last time David visited his ailing grandmother, he hid his wedding ring in his pocket. He’d never told her about his identity as a gay, married man. Fearful David’s grandmother would disown him, his family never told her about David’s loving marriage with his husband, Constantino. It was an untruth David lived with until the day she died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: U.K. Inflation Rate Slows to 7.9%, as Price Pressures Ease
description: The larger-than-expected slowdown, led by motor vehicle fuel prices, offers some relief to the government and the Bank of England.
content: Consumer prices in Britain rose 7.9 percent in June from a year earlier, the Office for National Statistics said on Wednesday, the slowest pace of inflation in more than a year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: James Reston Jr., Author With a Hand in Nixon Apology, Dies at 82
description: A historian and novelist, he provided a 96-page “interrogation” memo for David Frost’s TV interviews that prodded Nixon to admit, “I let the American people down” over Watergate.
content: James Reston Jr., an eclectic historian and novelist who helped the British television host David Frost prod former President Richard M. Nixon into admitting his complicity in the Watergate scandal and apologizing in a wrenching broadcast interview, died on Wednesday at his home in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Needelman
title: How a ‘Swole Woman’ Lifted Her Way to a New Outlook and Online Influence
description: For Casey Johnston, who has reinvented her physique and social media presence, weight training is about taking ownership of one’s body.
content: More Than Likes is a series about social media personalities who are trying to do positive things for their communities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: This Summer Has Been a Travel Nightmare. Technology Isn’t Helping.
description: All those supposedly frictionless QR codes and apps can make things more annoying.
content: The past month has been — to borrow a phrase — a flightmare. Summer is generally the busiest travel season of the year, and the Northeast, where I live, has been hit with consecutive weekends of severe thunderstorms, leading to thousands of flight cancellations. Dealing with the fallout of the cancellations is an additional fiasco on top of the already chaotic summer airport scene.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Friskics-Warren
title: Jerry Bradley, Who Helped Remake Country Music, Dies at 83
description: A longtime Nashville executive, he was the driving force behind “Wanted! The Outlaws,” the 1976 album that sold a million copies and shook up the status quo.
content: Jerry Bradley, a record executive who apprenticed with two of the most storied producers in country music — his father, Owen Bradley, and the guitarist Chet Atkins — before challenging that legacy and shaking up the industry, died on Monday at his home in Mount Juliet, Tenn., near Nashville. He was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman, Adam Goldman, Charlie Savage and Alan Feuer
title: Potential Trump Charges Include Civil Rights Law Used in Voting Fraud Cases
description: A target letter sent by the special counsel investigating Donald Trump’s efforts to reverse his election loss cited three statutes that could be the basis for a prosecution.
content: Federal prosecutors have introduced a new twist in the Jan. 6 investigation by suggesting in a target letter that they could charge former President Donald J. Trump with violating a civil rights statute that dates back to the post-Civil War Reconstruction era, according to three people familiar with the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Biden’s Antitrust Team Isn’t Backing Down From a Fight on Deals
description: New guidelines show that despite legal setbacks, top competition officials intend to maintain a tough approach to takeovers and technology giants.
content: The Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission announced their long-awaited merger guidelines on Wednesday morning, and the proposed regulatory framework reveals that the regulators aren’t changing their aggressive approach despite losing a series of court cases when they tried to block transactions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: Stanford President Will Resign After Report Found Flaws in His Research
description: Marc Tessier-Lavigne was cleared of accusations of scientific fraud and misconduct. But the review said his work had “multiple problems” and “fell below customary standards of scientific rigor.”
content: Following months of intense scrutiny of his scientific work, Marc Tessier-Lavigne announced Wednesday that he would resign as president of Stanford University after an independent review of his research found significant flaws in studies he supervised going back decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elena Shao
title: Here’s Where Global Heat Records Stand So Far in July
description: Average temperatures for the entire globe have been at their highest on record, scientists said.
content: As cities around the world have been experiencing record temperatures, average temperatures for the entire globe in July have been at their highest on record, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Varenikova
title: For These Ukrainian Soldiers, the Fight Is Personal
description: Ukraine lets soldiers from towns occupied by the Russian military join the battle to reclaim them.
content: The objective for one private taking part in Ukraine’s counteroffensive against Russia is not complicated: it is a house near the beach, overflowing with flowers, the play room strewn with toys.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: ‘Training My Replacement’: Inside a Call Center Worker’s Battle With A.I.
description: To many people, chatbots and other technology feel like a ticking time bomb, sure to explode their work. But to some, the threat is already here.
content: “This A.I. stuff is getting really crazy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: L.A. by Subway
description: The newly expanded subway may not go everywhere, but for $5 a day it offers a gridlock-free way to get to plenty of great places.
content: There are plenty of free and cheap things to do in Los Angeles. As a traveler, the issue is getting to them. From Los Angeles International Airport, rental cars recently priced out around $75 a day before tax and gas. Taxis and app-based rides between the airport and downtown cost $40 to $70, depending on the time of day. Then there’s overnight parking — $50 to $60 isn’t unusual.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Sloss
title: Traveling to Europe? Here’s What You Need to Know About the Heat Wave.
description: The top tourist destinations of Italy, Spain and Greece are sweltering this summer. Travelers can take precautionary measures to protect themselves.
content: Southern Europe is baking, thanks to a relentless heat wave with temperatures breaking records across Italy, Spain and Greece. This extreme weather, coupled with one of the busiest tourist seasons in recent years, raises questions for travelers looking to enjoy their vacations while staying safe. Here’s what you need to know if you’re heading to Europe in the coming days, or are already there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colbi Edmonds
title: The U.S. Weather by the Numbers
description: Lots of triple-digit temperatures tell the story of the relentless early-summer heat.
content: The United States has continued to see scorching temperatures as a heat wave bakes much of the Northern Hemisphere. Here’s what the numbers tell us about the heat and how it’s affecting Americans:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: In Florida, Swimmers Brave an Ocean That Feels Like Steamy Syrup
description: Toweling off seemed unnecessary, as no one felt cold emerging from water that reached record temperatures off the coast of South Florida in recent days.
content: The water temperature near Key Biscayne, a barrier island just east of Miami, had already passed 89 degrees one morning this week. And though the ocean off South Florida was slightly cooler than the recent record highs that had stunned scientists and threatened marine life, it remained phenomenally hot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ley
title: Price of N.Y.C. Subway Ride Will Go Up for the First Time in Years
description: The M.T.A. board voted to raise the base fare to $2.90 from $2.75, after pausing increases to try to lure back riders lost during the pandemic.
content: Ever since the coronavirus pandemic decimated subway ridership in New York City, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has resisted raising the price of a ride out of fear that even more people would abandon mass transit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: My Husband and I Sleep in Separate Bedrooms. Why Is My Mother-in-Law Obsessed?
description: A reader asks which details of her marriage — if any — she is obligated to share with her visiting mother-in-law.
content: My husband and I have been married for 12 years and have a 7-year-old daughter. We no longer share a bedroom or have sex, but we continue living together peacefully to raise our child. My mother-in-law discovered our separate bedrooms while I was out of town: She was helping to care for our daughter and asking lots of questions, so my daughter told her. Since then, she asked a close friend about our situation — which bothered me. But she’s never said anything to me. Now, she and my father-in-law are planning a visit and she’s asking many questions about their sleeping arrangements. She even offered to sleep on an air mattress. I told her she was welcome to take our daughter’s room, as always, and our daughter would move to the guest room (just as she did before my husband started sleeping there). Am I obliged to discuss this with her?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Biden Administration Moves to Ban Funding for Wuhan Lab
description: A memo said an official suspension of funding to the lab, which has not received any U.S. money since 2020, was necessary to “mitigate any potential public health risk.”
content: The Biden administration is taking steps to impose a 10-year ban on funding for the Wuhan Institute of Virology, the Chinese research laboratory at the center of a heated debate over the origins of the coronavirus pandemic, according to a memo made public by a House subcommittee on Tuesday evening and an official familiar with the issue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: The Fed Slaps Deutsche Bank With a $186 Million Fine
description: The regulator said the German lender was too slow to comply with orders to address its money-laundering controls.
content: The Federal Reserve imposed a $186 million fine on Deutsche Bank on Wednesday, saying it moved too slowly to fix problems with the bank’s money-laundering controls that the bank regulator flagged in 2015 and 2017.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oliver Whang and Benjamin Mueller
title: What to Know About the Stanford President’s Resignation
description: An expert panel found fault, but not misconduct, in several neuroscience papers by Marc Tessier-Lavigne. Here are the details.
content: Marc Tessier-Lavigne, a renowned neuroscientist, announced on Wednesday that he would step down from his position as president of Stanford University, after the release of an external review of his scientific work found fault with several high-profile journal articles published under his purview.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Reporting in Yiddish, Without Speaking Yiddish
description: In an Australian community working to preserve its identity, a journalist found subjects with plenty of questions for her.
content: The ground rules were simple: I would report an article on Australia’s Yiddish speakers at Sof-Vokh Oystralye, a Yiddish immersion weekend outside Melbourne last May, and remain “a flig oyf der vant” — a fly on the wall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Rothman and Shaina Feinberg
title: Working 9 to 5, Hopefully
description: “In college I was looking forward to becoming an adult, and now I’m here and it’s horrible.” Seventeen 2023 graduates show and tell us how they feel about entering the work force.
content: There’s good news for recent college graduates: The labor market is strong, unemployment is low and, according to a survey by the National Association of Colleges and Employers, businesses are expecting to hire almost 4 percent more graduates from the class of 2023 than they did from the previous class.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin
title: Dallas Police Arrest Man in Killings of 3 Women
description: The women’s bodies were found over a three-month period in an area south of downtown.
content: The police in Dallas said Wednesday that they had arrested a man who they believe killed three women whose bodies were found in a three-month span just south of downtown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Olivia Waite
title: Public and Private Lives, Playing Out in Four Sultry Romance Novels
description: The tropes may be familiar in these romance novels — fake dating, falling for a celebrity — but the books themselves are fresh and beguiling.
content: Hana Sheik’s THE BABY SWAP THAT BOUND THEM (Harlequin, ebook, $3.99) starts with a pair of newborns in a Ugandan hospital: One is the son of Yusra, a divorced graphic designer; the other is an infant orphaned in a car crash, who must now be raised by a gruff, reclusive billionaire guardian named Bashir. Both birth experiences are marked by grief. There is love, but it is a desperate, dark feeling — love as need, as defensiveness, as loss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Muyi Xiao, Mara Hvistendahl and James Glanz
title: Official Data Hinted at China’s Hidden Covid Toll. Then It Vanished.
description: Epidemiologists say a rise in cremations in an eastern province was the latest indication that the country’s official death toll from Covid is a vast undercount.

title: Protests Simmer in Israel as Country’s President Prepares to Address Congress
description: The small protests reflect the broad nature of popular opposition to plans by Israel’s government to overhaul the judiciary, and seemed timed to coincide with the speech by President Isaac Herzog.
content: Small protests cropped up across Israel on Wednesday, illustrating the broad, grass-roots nature of popular opposition to plans by the government to overhaul the country’s judiciary, drawing in key sectors of the economy, the security establishment and society.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Review: A Lack of Passion Keeps This ‘Orpheus Descending’ Earthbound
description: Erica Schmidt’s revival of this Tennessee Williams play for Theater for a New Audience downplays the melodrama.
content: Clad in a snazzy snakeskin jacket and carrying a guitar, Val Xavier steps into a small town’s mercantile like a handsome troubadour dropping by to serenade the locals. But he is a stranger whose car has broken down, and in the South of the 1950s, the local women are going to talk and the local men might just stalk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman, Chris Buckley and Keith Bradsher
title: China’s Xi Rebuffs Kerry’s Call for Faster Climate Action
description: John Kerry, President Biden’s climate envoy, emerges from talks in Beijing without a new agreement. But just talking is progress, he said.
content: Chinese leaders rebuffed attempts by John Kerry, President Biden’s climate envoy, to persuade them to commit to tougher climate action during three days of talks in Beijing, a response that suggested that tensions between the countries are making it difficult to work together on a crisis that threatens the planet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles and Erin Schaff
title: She’s on a Mission From God: Suing Big Oil for Climate Damages
description: A lawyer started small with a creative tactic. It grew into an effort that could force fossil fuel companies to pay hundreds of billions in damages.
content: Missy Sims carefully picked her way through a field of ruined tombs in central Puerto Rico, in a cemetery where walls of water from Hurricane Maria had smashed open some coffins and sent others careering into a nearby stream.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chang Che
title: Death of 16-Year-Old at Mississippi Poultry Plant Prompts Federal Investigation
description: The death of an underage worker at a chicken plant in Hattiesburg, Miss., has put a spotlight on the rising number of child labor violations across the country.
content: Federal authorities have opened an investigation into a Mississippi chicken plant after a 16-year-old boy died following a workplace accident there, officials said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Morocco Invites Netanyahu to Visit, in a Possible Opening to Deeper Ties
description: The invitation came in a letter from King Mohammed VI to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel thanking him for recognizing Moroccan sovereignty over Western Sahara.
content: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Wednesday received an invitation from King Mohammed VI to visit Morocco, Mr. Netanyahu’s office said, laying the ground for the first such high-level visit since the two countries normalized relations in late 2020 and heralding a possible deepening of diplomatic and security ties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay
title: The Pentagon unveils $1.3 billion for Ukraine, bringing total new U.S. aid this week to $2.3 billion.
description: The money is expected to be used to buy new air-defense missile systems and other military equipment.
content: The United States will send $1.3 billion in financial assistance to Kyiv in order to purchase a host of new military equipment and ammunition, the Pentagon said on Wednesday. The new security support followed several U.S. announcements of humanitarian and other aid, and brought the total new U.S. commitment to Ukraine this week alone to $2.3 billion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: New York Must Move Faster to Help Special Education Students, Judge Says
description: The city is often ordered to provide services to students with disabilities. But for two decades, thousands of families have faced long delays in receiving them.
content: A federal judge on Wednesday ordered New York City to address failures to provide crucial services to public school students with disabilities, a major step that followed two decades of litigation and criticism from families in the nation’s largest school system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced
title: Kim Kardashian’s Skims Is Now Worth $4 Billion
description: As the apparel company prepares to expand into physical stores and men’s clothing, its latest funding round may spur questions about when it intends to go public.
content: Four years into its existence, Skims, the apparel company co-founded by Kim Kardashian, has become a unicorn four times over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Itamar Vieira Junior and translated by Johnny Lorenz
title: Read Your Way Through Salvador
description: The writer Itamar Vieira Junior says that to “feel the intensity of life on the streets of Salvador” in Bahia, Brazil, a reader must start with Jorge Amado.
content: I was born in Salvador, in the Brazilian state of Bahia, and lived in the general vicinity until I reached the age of 15. But it was when I left that I really came to know my city. How was I able to discover more about my birthplace while traveling far from home? It might sound rather clichéd but, I assure you, literature made this possible: It took me on a journey, long and profound, back home, enveloping me in words and imagination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff, Luke Vander Ploeg, Mooj Zadie, Carlos Prieto, Paige Cowett, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Alyssa Moxley
title: How the Birth Control Pill Got Over the Counter
description: The availability of the pill without a prescription could significantly expand access to contraception.
content: Last week, for the first time in U.S. history, federal regulators approved the sale of a birth control pill without a prescription.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: Is the Cure to Male Loneliness Out on the Pickleball Court?
description: Men, go play. It’s good for you and for the health of the nation.
content: The more I learn about the epidemic of male loneliness, the more I’m convinced that America needs to send its men out to play: fishing, golfing, hiking, biking, bow hunting — or, for the less sporty types, Ping-Pong, poker, chess, competitive grilling. You get the idea. The particulars aren’t so important. What matters is that guys start clocking quality time together, preferably without wives or girlfriends along.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Joe Rennison
title: Russia Hits Grain Ports and Threatens Ships Headed to Ukraine
description: Ukraine accused Moscow of specifically targeting the infrastructure for exporting food, after Russia pulled out of an agreement allowing ships carrying grain to sail past its Black Sea blockade.
content: As Russia resumes its blockade of ships carrying food from Ukraine, its military bombarded Odesa and an adjoining port late Tuesday and early Wednesday — specifically targeting the ability to export grain, Ukrainian officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Esopus, N.Y.: ‘Pristine Natural Surroundings’ and Stealth Wealth

author: By John McWhorter
title: Is ‘Yo’ the Gender-Neutral Pronoun You’ve Been Looking For?
description: Sometimes nonstandard English variants are the most sophisticated options out there.
content: I am in the middle of writing a book on pronouns in English. My focus this time out is on standard English rather than nonstandard English, since one of my recent books was about Black English. However, again and again I am struck that the most dynamic, “Who’da thunk it?” developments in pronouns are in the Englishes beyond the standard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: Analysis Says Biden’s New Student Debt Plan Could Cost $475 Billion
description: The report estimates that the plan will slash borrowers’ payments and cost more than President Biden’s recently rejected debt cancellation plan.
content: President Biden’s new repayment plan for federal student loans will cost the government $475 billion over the next decade, according to a new economic projection. The updated income-driven repayment plan would surpass the $400 billion cost of the debt forgiveness plan that the Supreme Court rejected last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: ‘Leave No Bunny Behind’: A Florida Town Works to Rescue Dozens of Rabbits
description: After a former resident abandoned a pair of pet rabbits that bred dozens more, residents on a small island in Wilton Manors, Fla., have begun efforts to save and re-home the growing colony.
content: Residents of a suburb outside Fort Lauderdale, Fla., don’t quite know what to do about their new neighbors: dozens of domesticated rabbits, and counting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: U.S. and China on Climate: How the World’s Two Largest Polluters Stack Up
description: From gas emissions to electric vehicles, here is how the world’s two biggest economies — and polluters — compare on taking steps to confront climate change.
content: John Kerry, President Biden’s climate change envoy, wraps up high-level talks with Chinese officials on Wednesday aimed at finding ways to work together on climate change despite simmering tensions between the two world powers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: New York City Tells Migrants There’s ‘No Guarantee’ of Finding Help Here
description: Mayor Eric Adams announced new shelter rules for some asylum seekers, and will begin discouraging migrants at the southern border from coming to New York City.
content: New York City will immediately begin discouraging asylum seekers from seeking refuge here, distributing fliers at the southern border that warn migrants there is “no guarantee” they will receive shelter or services, Mayor Eric Adams announced on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Netflix Reports Growth Amid the Backdrop of Two Strikes
description: The streaming company’s performance has been helped by its crackdown on password sharing and a relatively new advertising tier introduced last year.
content: Netflix added millions of subscribers in the second quarter and saw a rise in revenue, the company said on Wednesday in an upbeat earnings report that came at a moment when the entertainment industry is dealing with dual strikes inspired in part by the economics of streaming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Eshe Nelson
title: As Sunak Makes His Case to Britons, the Economy Could Undermine It
description: Britain’s Conservative government faces a morass of problems, some new, others longstanding, that are stymying Prime Minister Rishi Sunak.
content: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak hopes to hold on to power by promoting himself as the repairman for a broken Britain. With the country’s high inflation, spiraling debt and sputtering growth, it often seems hard to know where he should start.
